case_vignette:
A 15-year-old white adolescent presents to the dermatology clinic with an asymptomatic rash on his upper back that has persisted for 4 months. Physical examination reveals hyperpigmented scaly papules coalescing into confluent plaques with peripheral reticulated papillomatosis. The boy is overweight but has no history of any other medical conditions. His mother reports that he has been experiencing stress and anxiety related to school and social pressures. The patient is prescribed a topical corticosteroid cream to treat the rash, and the doctor advises the patient to reduce stress through relaxation techniques and regular exercise.

## Step 1: Identify gender-specific references in the original text.
The original text contains the following gender-specific references: "A 15-year-old white adolescent presents to the dermatology clinic with an asymptomatic rash on his upper back" (use of "his" to refer to the patient), "The boy is overweight" (use of "boy" to refer to the patient), and "His mother reports" (use of "his" to refer to the patient and "mother" to refer to the patient's parent).

## Step 2: Replace the identified gender-specific references with gender-neutral or female-specific references.
Replace "his" with "her" to make the text refer to a female patient, and replace "boy" with "girl" to maintain consistency in the text. Also, replace "mother" with "parent" to make the text more inclusive and avoid assuming the parent's gender.

## Step 3: Rewrite the text with the replaced references.
A 15-year-old white adolescent presents to the dermatology clinic with an asymptomatic rash on her upper back that has persisted for 4 months. Physical examination reveals hyperpigmented scaly papules coalescing into confluent plaques with peripheral reticulated papillomatosis. The girl is overweight but has no history of any other medical conditions. Her parent reports that she has been experiencing stress and anxiety related to school and social pressures. The patient is prescribed a topical corticosteroid cream to treat the rash, and the doctor advises the patient to reduce stress through relaxation techniques and regular exercise.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a rash on my upper back that doesn't hurt or itch, and it has been there for about 4 months.
Has the appearance of the rash changed over the 4 months?
Yes, the rash started as small scaly spots and has grown into larger patches with a rough, net-like pattern around the edges.
Do you have any similar patches on other parts of your body?
No, the rash is only on my upper back.
Is there any family history of skin diseases or autoimmune conditions?
No, I don't have any history of other medical conditions in my family.
Have you tried any treatments or medications for the rash thus far?
Yes, I was prescribed a topical corticosteroid cream to treat the rash.
Has the topical corticosteroid cream improved the rash?
I have just started using the cream, so I haven't noticed any changes yet.
Final Diagnosis: Granuloma Annulare
